speaker: Clinician
text: Okay, Sandra, I can see the numbers on your home cuff are still running in the 150s over mid-90s, and that explains why the pharmacy computer cut you off after thirty pills, because it assumed you should have improved already. We’re bumping lisinopril up to forty milligrams once every morning, still with or without food. You don’t need a second trip; the pharmacist will simply give you the larger-strength tablet and tell you to start tomorrow. Take a moment to, uh, breathe—this isn’t a failure on your part. High blood pressure can be stubborn, especially with our family histories and a stressful commute.

speaker: Clinician
text: Things I want you to watch for: new dry cough that won’t quit, light-headed spells when you stand, swollen ankles, or anything that just feels off. If any of that pops up, call us even if it’s after hours—our exchange will page me, and I’d rather lose sleep than have you, I mean, faint in the stacks at work. Keep sipping water; dehydration makes lisinopril hit harder. Because the drive is so long, bring your pill bottle when you come to town, and we’ll, uh, run a quick kidney panel the same morning to make sure creatinine is holding steady.

speaker: Clinician
text: Let’s also tackle the refill crunch before it sneaks up again. I’m writing this as a ninety-day supply with two refills, but the insurance flags errors if the blood-pressure readings aren’t uploaded. So once a week email me a photo of your log—just the page, no selfies—and I’ll certify it in the system. That way the mail-order warehouse ships directly to your porch and you won’t burn gasoline chasing pills. Set a phone alarm for eight a.m.; consistency beats potency. And if a dose is missed, simply take it when you remember unless it’s nearly the next morning—never double.
